questions.text: Complications of liver trauma is/are:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Complications of liver trauma: Intrahepatic hematoma Liver abscess Bile collection Biliary fistula Arteriovenous fistula Hepatic artery aneurysm Arterio biliary fistula Liver failure

Highyeild:

Liver trauma can lead to various complications Subcapsular or intrahepatic hematoma typically resolves on its own without intervention Abscesses require systemic antibiotics and ultrasound-guided aspiration Bile collections require ultrasound-guided aspiration with or without drain insertion Biliary fistulae may be investigated with endoscopic or percutaneous cholangiography with or without stent insertion for biliary decompression Liver resection may be necessary if a fistula persists Late vascular complications of liver trauma may include hepatic artery aneurysms and arteriovenous fistulae Arterio-biliary fistulae may result in haemobilia and require embolisation Hepatic insufficiency is a possible complication Hepatic insufficiency may recover with supportive treatment if the blood supply and biliary drainage to an adequate liver remnant are preserved

questions.text: PAIR technique is used in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hydatid liver disease Treatment is indicated to prevent progressive enlargement and rupture of the cysts. In the first instance, a course of albendazole or mebendazole may be tried. There are many reports that percutaneous treatment of hydatid cysts is safe and effective. Percutaneous treatment (PAIR - Puncture Aspiration Injection Reaspiration ) constitutes of an initial course of albendazole followed by puncture of the cyst under image guidance, aspiration of the cyst’s contents, instillation of hypertonic saline in the cyst cavity and respiration . PAIR should only be attempted if there is no communication with the biliary tree. Failure to respond to medical treatment or percutaneous treatment usually requires surgical intervention. The surgical options range from liver resection or local excision of the cysts to deroofing with the evacuation of the contents.

Highyeild:

PAIR is the preferred method of treatment for anatomically and surgically appropriate lesions. PAIR has an efficacy rate of over 75% in managing hydatid cysts. Albendazole is given prophylactically to the patient during the PAIR procedure. Hypertonic (20%) saline is a scolicidal agent used during the procedure that is 100% effective with a contact time of 6 minutes. Other scolicidal agents used during the PAIR procedure includ e 0.5% cetrimide with 0.05% chlorhexidine, absolute alcohol, and 10% povidone-iodine.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . Pyogenic liver abscess is treated by drainage using a pigtail catheter under USG guidance if medical management fails. Option: B . Amebic liver abscess is treated by aspirating or drainage of the contents of the abscess after medical management fails. Option: D . All of the above cannot be the answer.

Extraedge:

The most common symptoms of pyogenic abscess include fever, right upper quadrant tenderness, and raised alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels . Amebic abscesses may present with abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and raised prothrombin time (PT) levels. Hydatid cysts may be asymptomatic or present with abdominal pain, right upper quadrant mass, and eosinophilia.

questions.text: Identify the sign shown in the following small bowel enema image in a patient with Crohn’s disease:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

String sign Image showing in small bowel enema, a narrowed terminal ileum involved with Crohn’s disease– the ‘string’ sign of Kantor. High-resolution ultrasound in expert hands can demonstrate inflamed and thickened bowel loops, as well as fluid collections and abscesses. The small intestine is traditionally imaged by a small bowel enema . This is performed by instilling contrast into the small bowel via a naso duodenal tube and will show up areas of stricturing, and prestenotic dilatation. The involved areas tend to be narrowed, irregular and, sometimes, when a length of the terminal ileum is involved, there may be the ‘string sign’ of Kantor.

Highyeild:

High-resolution ultrasound, when used by experts, can show inflamed and thickened bowel loops, fluid collections, and abscesses . It can also reveal the Kantor string sign. CT scans with oral contrast are commonly used to investigate abdominal symptoms and can detect intra-abdominal abscesses, bowel thickening or dilation, and fistulae. MRI is useful in assessing complex perianal disease and investigating the small bowel. Magnetic resonance enterography or enteroclysis, with oral contrast or contrast administered via a nasoduodenal tube, respectively, can effectively demonstrate small bowel stricturing and the Kantor string sign . MRI avoids repeated exposure to ionizing radiation in young patients.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A & B . These signs are seen in TB Option: D . The accordion sign is seen in pseudomembranous colitis

Extraedge:

A labeled white cell scan can be used to determine whether a segment of the bowel is actively inflamed and guide decisions on medical treatment. Fstulography is helpful in demonstrating the anatomy and complexity of an enterocutaneous fistula and planning for future surgery.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of fatigue and weight loss. Physical examination shows jaundice. The liver is palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin. Serum studies show an elevated alpha-fetoprotein and a prolonged prothrombin time. Genetic analysis of a liver biopsy specimen shows a G: C to T: A transversion in codon 249 of the gene coding for the TP53 protein in affected cells. Which of the following risk factors is most specific to the patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dietary aflatoxin exposure Signs of hepatocellular carcinoma and G: C → T: A transversion in codon 249 should raise suspicion for a history of aflatoxin B1 ingestion. Aflatoxin is produced by some strains of the mold Aspergillus . A metabolite of aflatoxin B1 interferes with proper DNA transcription of the TP53 gene through an inactivating mutation, resulting in the base transversions seen in this case. This mutation can be found in up to 60% of individuals with HCC in areas with high levels of exposure to aflatoxin B1.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Chronic alcoholism causes significant liver damage and is a common cause of liver cirrhosis , which is associated with roughly 80% of cases of hepatocellular carcinoma. However, if hepatocellular carcinoma develops due to cirrhosis, there is no specific mutation of the TP53 gene. Option: B. Chronic hepatitis C infection is a substantial risk factor for the development of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) . The majority of HCC cases can be attributed to chronic hepatitis B or C infection through a series of viral and non-viral pathophysiological steps. Nevertheless, the G: C → T: A transversion in the genetic analysis of this patient's liver biopsy is highly indicative of HCC of another etiology. Option: D . Patients who have contracted Schistosoma mansoni are at increased risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma because Schistosoma potentiates dysplastic changes induced by viral hepatitis or carcinogenic substances like diethylnitrosamine. However, this disease is not associated with a specific transversion in the TP53 gene.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man was brought to the emergency department for right upper quadrant abdominal pain that began 3 days ago. The pain is non-radiating and has no alleviating or exacerbating factors. He denies any nausea or vomiting. He immigrated from Mexico 6 months ago and currently works at a pet shop. He has been healthy except for 1 week of bloody diarrhea 5 months ago. His temperature is 101.8°F (38.8°C), the pulse is 85/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. He has tenderness to palpation in the right upper quadrant. Laboratory studies show: Leukocyte Count 14,000/mm Total bilirubin 0.4 mg/dL AST 76 U/L ALT 80 U/L Alkaline phosphatase 123 U/L Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows a 4-cm round, hypoechoic lesion in the right lobe of the liver with low-level internal echoes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Amoebiasis Amebiasis is caused by the protozoan Entamoeba histolytica . This pathogen is spread fecal-orally in endemic regions (Mexico, Southeast Asia, India) and causes both intestinal disease (bloody loose stools) and extraintestinal disease (amebic liver abscess). The history of bloody diarrhea and immigration from Mexico, as well as the presence of a solitary hypoechoic lesion in the liver, makes the diagnosis of amebiasis extremely likely. Patients with an amebic liver abscess typically present with fever and pain in the RUQ that is possibly exacerbated by inspiration.

Highyeild:

Entamoeba histolytica is a protozoan parasite with a global distribution that is mainly transmitted through contaminated drinking water. It can cause colonic ulcers that are described as "bottlenecked" due to their considerably undermined edges. These ulcers often have a yellow necrotic floor, from which blood and pus may exude. Amoebiasis can mimic ulcerative colitis clinically, with bloody diarrhea being the most common symptom. Severe complications such as hemorrhage, stricture formation, or perforation of the colon can occur. Pericolitis may result in adhesions that cause intestinal obstruction. Amoebiasis can cause liver abscesses or an amoebic mass (amoeboma) of the caecum or sigmoid, which can be difficult to distinguish from carcinoma. Surgery is risky because the bowel is extremely fragile.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B . Hepatic hydatid cyst is caused by the larvae of Echinococcus granulosus, a cestode that usually infects the gut of dogs. Human infection occurs by ingesting Echinococcus eggs. Patients may present with RUQ pain. The patient's occupational history (working in a pet store) is a risk factor for hepatic hydatid disease. However, fever is rare and occurs along with pruritus, urticaria, and/or anaphylaxis only if the cyst leaks or ruptures. The appearance of the cyst on ultrasonography varies depending on the stage of the cyst but a pathognomonic feature is the presence of daughter cysts and/or echogenic hydatid sand within the main cyst. Option: C. Although liver hemangiomas are the most common benign lesions of the liver, they are usually asymptomatic, found more commonly among women, and tend to be hyperechoic on ultrasonography. Option: D . Although patients with a pyogenic liver abscess also present with fever, right upper pain, leukocytosis, and a focal hypoechoic lesion in the right lobe of the liver, they are typically older (usually >50 years) and have an underlying bowel disease, intraabdominal infection, and/or a history of recent surgery. Moreover, nausea and vomiting, which are common findings in patients with pyogenic liver abscess, are not present in this patient. Lastly, a pyogenic liver abscess would not explain this patient's previous diarrhea.

Extraedge:

To diagnose amoebiasis, endoscopic biopsies or fresh stools are examined to look for the presence of amoebae. However, the presence of the parasite does not necessarily indicate that it is pathogenic. It is important to rule out amoebic infection in patients suspected of having ulcerative colitis. Treatment during the acute phase of the disease is metronidazole, while diloxanide furoate is effective against chronic infections associated with the passage of cysts in stools.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 3-month history of mild abdominal pain, nausea, and several episodes of vomiting. She often feels full after eating only a small amount of food. Abdominal examination shows mild right upper quadrant tenderness and a liver span of 15 cm. Ultrasonography shows a 4 x 4 cm hyperechoic mass in the left lobe of the liver. The mass is surgically excised. A photomicrograph of the resected specimen shows a vascular tumor. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cavernous hemangioma This patient's biopsy specimen shows a benign vascular tumor , which confirms the diagnosis of cavernous hepatic hemangioma . Cavernous hemangioma of the liver is the most common benign hepatic tumor and is typically seen in women aged 30–5 0 years. While most patients with hepatic hemangiomas are asymptomatic, a large hepatic hemangioma can compress the adjacent bowel (causing early satiety) and stretch the Glisson capsule (causing upper abdominal pain). Because hepatic hemangiomas are highly vascular, they typically appear as hyperechoic masses on ultrasonography. Needle aspiration or biopsy should be avoided in the diagnostic workup of hepatic hemangiomas due to the risk of hemorrhage.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Hepatocellular adenoma ( HA) is a benign tumor of the liver that is typically seen in women aged 20–45 years. HA mainly occurs in individuals on long-term use of oral contraceptives or steroids. HA is usually asymptomatic and is often detected incidentally. On sonography, HA is seen as a well-demarcated, heteroechoic intraparenchymal lesion. Histopathological features of HA include enlarged benign hepatocytes that contain glycogen and lipid deposits, which are not seen in this specimen. Option: C. Most individuals (75–90%) with polycystic kidney disease (PKD ) also have multiple hepatic cysts that typically manifest with right upper abdominal pain and hepatomegaly, which are seen in this patient. Unlike the specimen here, however, hepatic cysts in PKD are seen as multiple anechoic unilocular cysts on sonography, and histopathology would show cysts lined with cuboidal biliary epithelium and surrounded by normal hepatic parenchyma.

Extraedge:

Diagnosis is usually made using liver imaging studies. Caution must be exercised when ordering a liver biopsy for suspected hemangiomas due to the risk of bleeding. Surgical resection can be done through enucleation or formal hepatic resection , depending on the location and involvement of intrahepatic structures.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3.6-kg weight loss over the past 3 months and increasing fatigue. He was diagnosed with hepatitis C 6 years ago. His father died of colon cancer. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years and drinks one beer daily. He used cocaine and heroin in the past but stopped 12 years ago. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 79/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg. He appears weak and lethargic. Examination shows scleral icterus and scars on both cubital fossae. There is reddening of the palms bilaterally. There are several telangiectasias over the chest and back. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The liver is firm and of nodular consistency. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 11.6 g/dL Mean corpuscular volume 88 μm3 Leukocyte count 9,600/mm3 Platelet count 223,000/mm3 Ultrasonography of the liver shows a solitary lesion. Which of the following findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Elevated alpha feto-protein The patient has hepatitis C infection and now presents with liver cirrhosis and a solitary hepatic lesion on USG, making hepatocellular Carcinoma the most likely diagnosis. Both hepatitis infections and liver cirrhosis are risk factors for the development of hepatocellular carcinoma, which is usually asymptomatic except for features of the underlying disease. Further symptoms may occur in advanced disease stages, including weight loss, cachexia, ascites, and jaundice. Diagnostic features include the detection of a single hepatic lesion on ultrasound or CT and elevated levels of serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP).

Highyeild:

Hepatocellular Carcinoma: The most common primary liver malignancy is HCC HCC represents MC solid organ cancers HCC: MC malignancy responsible for death in patients with cirrhosis. More prevalent in Asia & sub-Saharan Africa ( high frequency of chronic infection with HBV & HCV ) 100 folds increase in risk in individuals with HBV infection More common in males, 60-90% arise in cirrhotic liver Post-necrotic cirrhosis has the highest risk of developing into HCC Alcoholic cirrhosis & Primary biliary cirrhosis has a lower risk The strong propensity for invasion of vascular channels Pathology: Gross Morphology : Hanging, pushing & invasive tumors Histologic patterns : Trabecular, pseudoglandular or acinar, compact pattern, and scirrhous pattern Clinical Features: MC symptom is abdominal pain, weight loss Non-specific symptoms (anorexia, weight loss) and Hepatomegaly Paraneoplastic Syndromes in HCC: Hypercholesterolemia (MC) >hypoglycemia, erythrocytosis, hypercalcemia Vascular bruit (25%), GI bleed (10%), tumor rupture (2-5%), jaundice due to biliary obstruction (10%), and paraneoplastic syndrome (<5%).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. In a patient with a solitary liver lesion on ultrasonography, positive blood culture s are indicative of a pyogenic liver abscess . Pyogenic liver abscesses most commonly develop secondary to biliary tract obstructions but may also be caused by bacteremia (e.g., in IV drug users). However, since this patient no longer actively consumes IV drugs, he is not at increased risk of bacteremia. While an abscess can be both the first manifestation or a complication of this patient's condition, in the absence of fever, malaise, RUQ pain, and leukocytosis, this diagnosis is less likely. Ultrasound findings would consist of a fluid-filled, hypoechoic lesion, unlike the solid, isoechoic lesion seen in this patient. Option: C . Elevated carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a tumor marker that is primarily elevated in patients with colorectal and pancreatic cancer. Although both types of cancer can metastasize to the liver, symptomatic metastatic disease is unlikely without any prior symptoms of the underlying malignancy (e.g., melena, hematochezia, epigastric pain). Option: D . Detection of an exophytic tumor on colonoscopy is diagnostic of colorectal cancer. The liver is most commonly affected by multiple metastases that are spread via the portal vein. While the patient has a family history of colorectal cancer and would require further workup to fully exclude a malignancy, in the absence of typical symptoms (e.g., hematochezia, changes in bowel habits, iron deficiency anemia) and the presence of hepatitis C and cirrhosis, another diagnosis is more likely.

Extraedge:

Non-invasive diagnostic criteria for HCC include a focal lesion 1-2 cm with two imaging techniques showing arterial hypervascularization and venous washout or a focal lesion >2 cm with one imaging technique showing arterial hypervascularization and venous washout. Complete excision by partial hepatectomy or by total hepatectomy and transplant is the only treatment modality with curative potential. Only 15-20% of HCC is resectable because the rest of the tumors have Multicentricity, Bilobar involvement, Portal vein invasion, and Lymphatic metastasis.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy comes to the physician for a follow-up after having an appendectomy 3 days ago. The patient was hospitalized for abdominal pain, vomiting, and fever; subsequent evaluation revealed early retro cecal appendicitis. He had an emergent appendectomy without any perioperative complications and was discharged home the next day. Today, his family noticed the yellowing of his eyes, but he has not had any abdominal pain or nausea since the surgery and is tolerating a normal diet. The patient does not use tobacco or alcohol. Temperature is 37 C, blood pressure is 118/80 mm Hg, and pulse is 68/min. On examination, there is mild scleral icterus. The cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Abdominal surgical incisions are healing well without any surrounding redness Laboratory results are as follows: Hemoglobin 14.4 g/dL Platelets 260,000/mm1 Leukocytes 7,500/mm' Liver function studies Total bilirubin 3.3 mg/dL Direct bilirubin 0.4 mg/dL Alkaline phosphatase 70 U/L Aspartate aminotransferase 27 U/L Alanine aminotransferase 24 U/L Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gilbert syndrome This patient with mild scleral icterus following appendectomy has elevated indirect (unconjugated) bilirubin levels (given his elevated total bilirubin level of 3.3 mg/dl without direct bilirubin predominance) with normal liver function test results and no evidence of hemolysis (given the normal hemoglobin level). This presentation is consistent with Gilbert syndrome, the most common inherited disorder of bilirubin glucuronidation. Gilbert syndrome is characterized by recurrent episodes of mild jaundice due to decreased activity of the UDP-glucuronosyltransferase enzyme, responsible for bilirubin conjugation in the liver. These episodes may be precipitated by stressors (eg, infection, fasting, vigorous exercise, surgery).

Highyeild:

Jaundice is characterized by the yellowing of the skin and eyes due to increased levels of bilirubin in the blood. Intrahepatic causes of jaundice involve the enzymatic processes within hepatocytes responsible for the conjugation and excretion of bile. Impairment of hepatic blood flow and subsequent liver function, such as ischemic or hypoxic events, can affect these processes. Inherited enzyme metabolism disorders can result in either unconjugated or conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Gilbert's syndrome is a genetic variant characterized by the diminished activity of the enzyme glucuronyltransferase, leading to decreased conjugation of bilirubin to glucuronide. Gilbert's syndrome usually results in transient mild increases in unconjugated bilirubin levels and jaundice during episodes of fasting, stress, or illness. Gilbert's syndrome is a benign condition that affects approximately 4% to 7% of the population and usually does not require further treatment.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Acalculous cholecystitis is an inflammatory condition of the gallbladder most commonly seen in critically ill, hospitalized patients. Laboratory results are nonspecific but often show a leukocytosis along with hyperbilirubinemia and sometimes mild elevation in alkaline phosphatase and aminotransferase levels. Option: B. Patients with acute viral hepatitis present with anorexia, nausea, and vomiting. Aminotransferase levels are extremely elevated (eg, >25x upper limits of normal). Option: C. Halogenated inhalational anesthetics (eg, halothane) are associated with severe hepatotoxicity. Due to this concern, halothane use is not recommended in adults. There are 2 types of halothane hepatotoxicity: a mild, self-limiting form characterized by mild elevations in aminotransferase levels, and a severe form that causes liver necrosis, fever, and jaundice with grossly elevated aminotransferase levels.

Extraedge:

Crigler-Najjar syndrome is a rare inherited disorder of bilirubin conjugation found in neonates. Crigler-Najjar syndrome can result in neurotoxic sequelae from bilirubin encephalopathy, making it a serious condition that requires medical attention.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the office due to abnormal liver chemistry results found during a life insurance medical examination. He occasionally feels fatigued and has pedal edema after prolonged standing but otherwise is well. The patient has no medical history and takes no medications. He drinks 1 or 2 cans of beer on weekends and does not smoke. He used intravenous drugs in his 20s but has not since then. Vital signs are within normal range. Physical examination shows palmar erythema and multiple spider angiomas. Laboratory results are as follows: Hemoglobin 11 .2 g/dl Liver function studies Albumin 3.4 g/dl Total bilirubin 1.3 mg/dl Aspartate 62U/L aminotransferase Alanine 99U/L aminotransferase INR 1.4 Hepatitis C virus antibody - positive Hepatitis C RNA - 1 million copies/ml Abdominal ultrasonography reveals a coarse, nodular-appearing liver with no masses, mild ascites, and splenomegaly. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy demonstrates medium-sized but nonbleeding esophageal varices. He is referred for a hepatitis C evaluation with a gastroenterologist. Which of the following is the best management for this patient at this time?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Beta-adrenergic receptor blockers This patient has evidence of cirrhosis (eg, spider angioma, nodular coarse liver, varices), likely from chronic hepatitis C . He is found to have medium-sized, nonbleeding esophageal varices. Variceal hemorrhage develops in approximately one-third of all patients with varices and is a major cause of morbidity and mortality. Most cirrhotic patients should undergo a diagnostic upper endoscopy to assess for chances and to determine their risk of hemorrhage. Those with (medium- or large-sized) varices, such as this patient, generally should be started on a nonselective beta blocker. Nonselective beta-blockers (eg, propranolol, nadolol) are recommended to decrease progression to large varices and the risk of variceal hemorrhage.

Highyeild:

Current measures aimed at preventing variceal bleeding include two main approaches : the administration of nonselective β-blockers and prophylactic endoscopic surveillance with variceal band ligation. Nonselective β-blockers such as propranolol and nadolol have been shown through meta-analyses to reduce the index variceal bleed by approximately 45% and decrease bleeding mortality by 50%. However, about 20% of patients do not respond to β-blockade, and another 20% cannot tolerate β-blockade due to medication side effects.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. ACE inhibitors have not been shown to reduce variceal bleeding or improve outcomes in cirrhosis, and they have no role in the management of patients with esophageal varices. Option: C . Endoscopic sclerotherapy is an effective treatment for actively bleeding esophageal varices. It is not recommended for primary prophylaxis of variceal hemorrhage. Option: D. H2 histamine receptor blockers have not been shown to reduce progression or bleeding complications in patients with cirrhosis and varices.

Extraedge:

Endoscopic surveillance involves frequent band ligation until variceal obliteration, followed by surveillance EGD every 6 months to monitor for variceal recurrence. Factors such as the patient's clinical profile and risk factors should be considered.

questions.text: A 19-year-old college student is brought to the emergency department by his girlfriend after he ingested large amounts of acetaminophen in a suicide attempt. Two days ago, the girlfriend told the patient that she wanted to break up with him. He became distraught and took approximately 30 pills of 500 mg acetaminophen to end his life. This morning, the girlfriend discovered what he had done and brought him to seek care. The patient reports nausea and mild abdominal pain. He has no history of previous suicide attempts or psychiatric illness. Temperature is 36.7 C, blood pressures 114/68 mm Hg, and pulse is 94/min. Abdominal examination reveals mild tender hepatomegaly. The serum acetaminophen level is high, and the patient is hospitalized for N-acetylcysteine therapy. During the hospital stay, he becomes markedly confused and incoherent. Repeat examination shows scleral icterus and asterixis. Current laboratory results and those obtained at the time of admission are as follows: At admission - Total bilirubin 1.2 mg/dl Aspartate aminotransferase 96 U/L Alanine aminotransferase 70 U/L Prothrombin time 18 sec Serum creatinine 1 .1 mg/dl Current - Total bilirubin 4.1 mg/dl Aspartate aminotransferase 8,456 U/L Alanine aminotransferase 9,634 U/l Prothrombin time 120 sec Serum creatinine 3.5 mg/dl Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Refer to the liver transplant center

questions.correct_answer: D. Refer to the liver transplant center
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Refer to the liver transplant center This patient has an acute liver failure (ALF) due to acetaminophen toxicity . ALF is defined as severe acute liver injury without underlying liver disease and is characterized by elevated aminotransferases (often >1,000 U/L), hepatic encephalopathy, and synthetic liver dysfunction (defined as prolonged prothrombin time [PT] with INR 1.5). Approximately only half of patients with ALF will survive without liver transplantation. Reliable indicators of worsening ALF include rising serum bilirubin and PT, as seen in this patient.

Highyeild:

Acute liver failure (ALF) occurs when the liver's regenerative capabilities are exceeded by the rate and extent of hepatocyte death. ALF is a rare disorder affecting approximately 2000 patients annually in the United States and is characterized by hepatic encephalopathy occurring within 26 weeks of severe liver injury in a patient without a history of previous liver disease or portal hypertension. ALF can cause cerebral edema, hemodynamic instability, increased susceptibility to infections, renal failure, coagulopathy, and metabolic disturbances. The most common cause of death from ALF is intracranial hypertension due to cerebral edema, followed by sepsis and multisystem organ failure. The causes of ALF can include viral infection as well as drug overdose, reaction, and toxicity, with differences in etiology, management, and patient outcomes described for various regions of the globe. Approximately 20% of all cases of ALF remain indeterminate in origin, even with exhaustive efforts to identify a cause. Clinical presentation of ALF can include jaundice, encephalopathy, and hepatic coma, and patients may be ill for a median of 6 days before the onset of encephalopathy. Diagnosis and clinical management of ALF include obtaining a medical history and performing a physical examination, laboratory evaluation, and liver biopsy if necessary.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Close monitoring alone would not be appropriate, and liver biopsy is unlikely to prevent the need for liver transplantation. Option: B. This patient's prolonged PT reflects coagulopathy due to ALF rather than due to vitamin K deficiency (often seen in patients with malnutrition). As a result, vitamin K supplementation will have a limited effect on this patient's coagulopathy. Option: C. Liver biopsy is sometimes helpful in ALF of unclear etiology. This patent's ALF is due to acetaminophen toxicity and his condition is worsening.

Extraedge:

Patients with ALF should be admitted to the hospital and monitored frequently, and a liver transplant center should be contacted early in the evaluation period due to the rapid progression of the disease. If acetaminophen overdose is suspected, administration of activated charcoal and N-acetylcysteine (NAC) may be useful as early as possible to reduce the volume of acetaminophen present in the GI tract and replenish glutathione.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician due to a 6-month history of fatigue, weakness, and intermittent nausea. He drinks 6-8 cans of beer daily. His blood pressure is 116/74 mm Hg and his pulse is 78/min. The patient is alert and oriented. He has significant muscle wasting and nontender enlargement of bilateral parotid glands. Multiple spider angiomas on the upper trunk and extremities are seen. Heart sounds are normal without murmur. Breath sounds are diminished at the right base. The abdomen is mildly distended with shifting dullness. Rectal examination reveals internal hemorrhoids, and stool is guaiac-negative. There Is no tremor, and neurologic examination is normal. Laboratory results are as follows: Platelets 105,000/mm Leukocytes 4,100/mm Total bilirubin 2.1 mg/dl Alkaline phosphatase 130 U/L Aspartate aminotransferase 282 U/L Alanine aminotransferase 120U/L Prothrombin time 12 sec Partial thromboplastin time 35 sec. Abdominal ultrasound reveals splenomegaly, ascites, and an echogenic, shrunken liver without any mass. After his clinical condition is discussed, the patient agrees to strictly follow medical recommendations. The patient is started on furosemide and spironolactone. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy reveals several medium distal esophageal varices. Which of the following additional interventions is most appropriate at this time?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nadolol The most important complication of cirrhosis t hat this patient faces is upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage from his medium esophageal varices. Patients with small varices that demonstrate bleeding risk factors or those with medium or large esophageal varices should receive primary prophylaxis to prevent bleeding. Primary prophylaxis can be achieved either with endoscopic variceal ligation (EVL) or the administration of a nonselective beta-blocker such as propranolol or nadolol.

Highyeild:

Current measures aimed at preventing variceal bleeding include two main approaches : the administration of nonselective β-blockers and prophylactic endoscopic surveillance with variceal band ligation. Nonselective β-blockers such as propranolol and nadolol have been shown through meta-analyses to reduce the index variceal bleed by approximately 45% and decrease bleeding mortality by 50%. However, about 20% of patients do not respond to β-blockade, and another 20% cannot tolerate β-blockade due to medication side effects.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Lactulose and rifaximin are treatments for hepatic encephalopathy, which commonly presents with confusion, neurologic impairment (eg, asterixis), or sleep disturbances. However, unlike variceal bleeding, hepatic encephalopathy does not typically require primary prophylaxis. Furosemide and spironolactone are first-line therapy for ascites due to cirrhosis. Option: B. Large-volume therapeutic paracentesis is indicated in case of respiratory compromise or significant abdominal discomfort, which this patient does not have. Option: C. ACE inhibitors such as lisinopril are mainstays in the management of hypertension, chronic kidney disease, and heart failure but do not have a role in the management of cirrhosis

Extraedge:

Endoscopic surveillance involves frequent band ligation until variceal obliteration, followed by surveillance EGD every 6 months to monitor for variceal recurrence. Factors such as the patient's clinical profile and risk factors should be considered.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after an episode of hematemesis and lightheadedness. He has a history of anemia, intravenous drug use, hepatitis C infection with cirrhosis, and alcohol use. The patient says he has had no alcohol in about 5 days. He takes no medications. His temperature is 36.7 C (98 F), blood pressure is 105/60 mm Hg, the pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 16/min. He has scleral icterus. Examination shows blood in the oropharynx. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is distended with a fluid wave. Laboratory results are as follows: International Normalized Ratio 1.8 Partial thromboplastin time 40 sec The patient receives normal saline through 2 large-bore intravenous lines and is started on ceftriaxone. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Octreotide infusion This patient with hepatitis C and alcoholic liver disease has an upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage , most likely due to esophageal varices . Initial treatment of suspected variceal bleeding includes volume resuscitation, through 2 to 3 large-bore peripheral intravenous lines. Prophylactic antibiotics (eg, ceftriaxone) should be given to cirrhotic patients with gastrointestinal bleeding to decrease infectious complications, recurrent bleeding, and mortality. questions.text: A 44-year-old man is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. Three weeks ago, he was hospitalized and treated for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. Examination shows scleral icterus and jaundice. There is 3+ pedal edema and reddening of the palms bilaterally. The breast tissue appears enlarged, and several telangiectasias are visible over the chest and back. Abdominal examination shows dilated tortuous veins. On percussion of the abdomen, the fluid-air level shifts when the patient moves from lying supine to right lateral decubitus. Breath sounds are decreased over both lung bases. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. A bilateral tremor is seen when the wrists are extended. Genital examination shows reduced testicular volume of both testes. questions.explanation:
Solution:

Recurrent variceal hemorrhage Based on available evidence, the indication currently most accepted for TIPS is variceal hemorrhage of the esophagus or stomach, either recurrent or acute, with treatment for acute variceal hemorrhage, indicated if pharmacologic and endoscopic treatment has failed. The procedure relieves the high portal venous pressure that causes varices to develop by bypassing the congested liver with a shunt from the portal vein to the hepatic vein.

Highyeild:

Variceal hemorrhage can be difficult to manage when pharmacological and endoscopic therapies fail. Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPSS) is now the preferred method for treating refractory portal hypertension. TIPSS involves th e insertion of a metallic stent under local anesthesia, analgesia, and sedation with the guidance of fluoroscopy and ultrasonography. The procedure involves inserting a guidewire through the hepatic parenchyma into a branch of the portal vein via the internal jugular vein, superior vena cava, and hepatic vein. TIPSS can result in complications such as perforation of the liver capsule, potentially fatal intraperitoneal hemorrhage, and occlusion of the stent. Post-TIPSS encephalopathy is a common complication and occurs due to portal blood avoiding hepatic detoxification. The main contraindication to TIPSS is portal vein occlusion, and long-term stenosis occurs in 50% of patients at one year. Despite the risks, TIPSS is still widely accepted as the preferred treatment for refractory portal hypertension when other treatments fail.

Patients with hepatic VOD may benefit from TIPS, but there is currently very little evidence to support the efficacy of the procedure. Option: C. In patients with portal hypertensive gastropathy, treatment with beta-blockers has been shown to reduce the severity of the condition as well as complications like bleeding. In severe cases involving resistant or frequently recurrent bleeding, patients may benefit from TIPS as an alternative therapy. While this procedure is sometimes used to treat portal hypertensive gastropathy, clear evidence regarding its efficacy in this clinical context is lacking. Option: D . Hepatic encephalopathy (HE) is caused by a buildup of neurotoxic metabolic products (e.g., ammonia) that occurs in patients with hepatic dysfunction. TIPS impairs ammonia clearance because serum-containing ammonia bypasses the liver; TIPS placement can, therefore, exacerbate HE and is contraindicated in this condition. However, serum ammonia levels are not always reliable and poorly correlate with the clinical manifestations of hepatic encephalopathy. Its use in assessing patients with cirrhosis of the liver is controversial. For this reason, the decision of whether or not to perform TIPS should not be based on serum ammonia levels.

A biopsy of the lesion would put this patient at the greatest risk for which of the following complications?

Hepatic hemangioma is a benign tumor composed of cavernous vascular spaces of variable size that are lined by flat endothelial cells. They are most common in women between the ages of 30-50 years old and may become enlarged during hormonal therapy. Most hepatic hemangiomas are asymptomatic and diagnosed incidentally on imaging, appearing hyperechogenic (due to increased vascularity), well-demarcated, and homogeneous. Being a highly vascular tumor, a biopsy represents a high risk of severe hemorrhage and is not recommended unless the diagnosis is uncertain.

They occur in 2% to 20% of the population, mostly in women. Small hemangiomas usually have no clinical consequence , but larger masses can cause symptoms due to compression or thrombosis. Surgical resection can be considered for symptomatic patients.

Solution:

Ascending infection from a biliary tract pathology, such as cholangitis , is the most common cause of hepatic abscesses. The infection is typically caused by bacteria and mainly is polymicrobial, with E. coli being the most frequent causative pathogen. Hepatic abscesses may also result from intraabdominal infections (e.g., acute appendicitis, peritonitis), or hematogenous spread from systemic circulation (e.g., sepsis).

Liver abscesses are more likely to occur in the elderly , those with diabetes, and the immunosuppressed. The typical presentation includes anorexia, fever, malaise, and discomfort in the right upper quadrant. The overall mortality rate has declined due to improved imaging and effective antimicrobial therapy.
